text: BF market id's are def not random enough. I pull list of market id's from sql db ordered by event date where rownumber % splitsWanted = n to get each set. Seems to work well enough for me and repeatable.

text: Fo example, I will run a bunch of stuff strategies on a market. Some bet £10. Some bet £20. I wouldn't want all the £10 strategies assigned to A. And all the £20 strategies assigned to B. I've been thinking that for this test I probably want a different seed for each pair or £10/£20 strategies.

text:
I think you can simplify this to

```def _get_rand_context(market_id: str, context: list[dict]) -> dict:
    id_ = int(market_id[2:])
    r = (0.5 + _INVERSE_GOLDEN_RATIO * id_) % 1
    return context[int(r // (1 / len(context))]```

elements.text: I think you can simplify this to

def _get_rand_context(market_id: str, context: list[dict]) -> dict:
    id_ = int(market_id[2:])
    r = (0.5 + _INVERSE_GOLDEN_RATIO * id_) % 1
    return context[int(r // (1 / len(context))]

text:
No I haven't because of my emphasis on reproducibility. But I think seeding it is as simple as adding your seed to the number you pass in. i.e

```random_from_positive_int(seed + market_id)```
